To manufacture efficient and cost-effective catalysts for soot combustion, SnO2 nano-rod (SnO2-Rod), nano-cube (SnO2-NP-Cube) and regular nanoparticles (SnO2-NP) have been designed as supports for Pd. The soot combustion activity ranks as 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube > 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod > 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP. The active oxygen amount of the supports increases as SnO2-Rod < SnO2-NP < SnO2-NP-Cube, which affects significantly Pd valence state distributions. On SnO2-NP-Cube, Pd is highly oxidized with 30.3 % Pd4+ and 69.7 % Pd2+. On SnO2-NP, nearly 100 % Pd2+ is present. On SnO2-Rod, Pd is more reduced with 73.4 % Pd0 and 26.6 % Pd2+. The concerted action of surface active oxygen and dual Pd valence states determines the activity. In detail, the active oxygen sites devote directly to soot oxidation via a Mars-van-Krevelen mechanism with a redox-cycle. The presence of dual Pd valence states on 0.5 % SnO2-NP-Cube and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod can promote this redox-cycle, thereby improving the soot combustion activity evidently. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Soot combustion Pd/SnO2 catalysts Low Pd content Morphology control Pd valence state distributions Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Soot particulates emissions from diesel engines are hazardous to environment and human health [1,2]. With the combination of a DOC catalyst and a DPF honeycomb, catalytic combustion is testified to be an efficient way to eliminate soot particulates. Up to date, different catalysts have been researched, such as alkaline metal oxides, ceria-based oxides, perovskite-like type oxides, mullite-type mixed oxides and A2B2O7 compound, [3–10] among which supported noble metals (Au, Pt, Pd) exhibit the best activity [11,12]. However, their high cost and risking supply have driven people to search for more cost effective alternatives. At present, developing non-noble metal catalysts and catalysts with low noble metal contents having competitive performance are regarded as two effective approaches [13–23]. Wu et al. [21] compared monocrystalline CeO2 nano-cubes, polycrystalline CeO2 nanoparticles and spindles for soot oxidation, and reported that the initial activity is controlled by the number of catalyst-soot contact points, but the stability is related to the surface oxygen vacancy amount. Shimizu et al. [22] reported the aging effect in air at 1000 °C on Ag supported over SnO2, CeO2, ZrO2, TiO2 and MgO, and found that Ag/SnO2 is the most effective catalysts owing to the presence of active Ag−O−Sn interfacial bonds. Wang et al. [24] prepared α-MnO2 with nanoflower-like and nanowire morphology by hydrothermal method to support Ag, and revealed that flower-like α-MnO2 promoted soot oxidation significantly due to the existing of the biggest amount of surface oxygen vacancies, which can form highly reactive superoxide (O2 −). SnO2 is an n-type oxide with rich active oxygen species and good stability, which is a promising catalytic material. [25–27] Since 2010, we have systematically studied its catalysis chemistry for quite some reactions. [28–32]. It was diclosed that SnO2 nano-rod show similar catalytic behavior to noble metals due to the preferentially exposed (110) planes. [28]. Furthermore, modifying the matrix of nano-rod SnO2 with In, Cr, and Al ions can further upgrade the activity, and an Al-doped SnO2 catalyst shows the best activity for toluene deep oxidation due to its optimal active surface oxygen and acidic sites. [29]. Moreover, Ji et al. [33] reported that Au supported on SnO2 crystallites with different morphologies for benzene and methanol oxidation. It was revealed that the specifically differed interactions between Au and SnO2 have a great impact on the reactivity of the oxygen sites. Li et al. [34] investigated the influence of support calcination temperature (600 −1200 °C) on the SnO2-supported Pd catalysts for CH4 combustion, and found that lattice matching based on PdO and SnO2 geometry improves oxygen activation on oxygen vacancies from SnO2 surface to PdO/Pd surface, which eventually enhances the reaction performance. Domashevskaya et al. [35] studies the surface doping of SnOx nanolayers with Pd, and detected the presence of Pd0, Pd2+ and Pd4+ components, among which Pd2+ is the most intense. Wang et al. [23] reported SnO2-R nano-rod and SnO2-P nano-particle supports with ultra-low Pd content for toluene deep oxidation. They testified that a certain quantity of Pd0 is formed extra to Pd2+ over Pd/SnO2-R, which is more important for the reaction than the active oxygen sites. In brief, these studies have indicated that the valence states of noble metals can significantly influence the catalytic activity in various redox reactions [36–52]. By summarizing these former interesting publications, it is concluded that the nature of the supports can affect the active surface oxygen properties and valence states of the supported noble metals significantly, which can in turn impact the interfacial interaction between the noble metals and the oxide supports. Therefore, through adjusting the properties of a support, there is the possibility to obtain highly efficient catalysts, hence reducing the noble metal content. Based on this idea, SnO2 supports with varied morphologies, that is, nano-cube, nano-particle and nano-rod, have been purposely synthesized as supports for Pd in this work. Three typical 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts were thus prepared for soot combustion. With multiple characterization methods, it is discovered that the valence state distributions of the dispersed Pd species can be significantly affected by the morphology/nature of the supports, thus resulting in varied soot combustion actvity. The predominant factors deciding the activity have been elucidated in-depth. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the SnO2 supports Three SnO2 supports with different morphologies, that is, SnO2 nano-rod (SnO2-Rod), regular nanoparticles (SnO2-NP) and nano-cube (SnO2-NP-Cube), have been synthesized with different methods as supports. The SnO2 nano-rod and the SnO2-NP-Cube support are produced by hydrothermal method, the SnO2-NP support was prepared by a simple precipitation method. The detailed procedures are included in the Supplementary Material file. 2.2 Synthesis of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts With a wetness impregnation method, three 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts were prepared, which are named 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod, 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube according to the morphology of the supports. As confirmed with ICP-OES in Table 1, the Pd content is the same to 0.5 %, the planned composition, within the experimental error for all the catalysts. 0.5 % Pd/Al2O3, the comparison catalyst, was prepared with the same procedure. The detailed procedures for the catalyst preparation are described in the Supplementary Material file. 2.3 Catalyst characterization and activity tests The structural properties of the catalysts were probed by multiple means, such as SEM, TEM, ICP-OES, XRD, N2 sorption, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, soot-TPR, in-situ DRIFTS, Raman spectroscopy, EPR, HRTEM, and XPS. The experimental conditions, apparatus models and operation procedures are explained in detail in the Supplementary Material file. 2.4 Activity evaluation Temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) technique was used to evaluate the activity of the prepared catalysts for soot combustion using a FINESORB-3010 C multiple adsorption instrument (Finetec, China). Tests were carried out in a fixed-bed quartz tube micro-reactor with an inner diameter of 6 mm. To evaluate the activity of a catalyst under tight contact condition, typically, 5 mg soot (Printex-U, diameter of 25 nm, purchased from Degussa) was mixed with 50 mg catalyst powder and grounded for 10 min. Before loading into the reactor, the grounded mixture was diluted by 100 mg inert silica with a soot/catalyst/silica weight ratio of 1/10/20 to avoid the formation of hot spots during the activity test. A K-type thermocouple was used to monitor the temperature of the catalyst bed accurately with the thermocouple head point touching the catalyst bed. To measure the reaction behaviors of the catalysts, all data were collected with the increasing of the temperature to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1. The volume composition of the feed gas is 10 % O2 and balanced by high purity Ar, with a flow rate of 30 mL min–1. The QMS-1800 mass spectrometer (Finetec, China) was used to detect the products. The mass spectrum signal m/z = 44 and 28 was used to detect the generation of CO2 in the exhaust gas, and m/z = 28 and 16 is used to detect the generation of CO in the exhaust gas. Since the CO2 molecules are able to split into m/z = 28 fragments, which is overlapped with the main CO signal, the quantification of CO amount needs to subtract the contribution from CO2. First, with 5 injections of pure CO2 under the same condition, an average splitting ratio f (f = A28/A44) was obtained to calculate the contribution of the m/z = 28 fragments from CO2. Then, at a certain temperature, the accurate relative amount of CO product (ACO) can be defined as AT-CO = A28 − A44 × f, and the accurate relative amount of CO2 product (ACO2) can be defined as AT-CO2 = A44 × (1 + f). Similarly, for a complete TPO reaction, the totally released amount of CO2 (AMax-CO2) and CO (AMax-CO) can be defined in the same way. Therefore, the conversion of soot particles (Xsoot) and the CO2 selectivity (SCO2) at a certain temperature can be calculated by formula (1) and (2) in sequence: (1) X soot = A T − CO + A T − CO 2 A Max − CO + A Max − CO 2 * 100 % (2) S CO 2 = A Max − CO 2 A Max − CO 2 + A Max − CO * 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 SEM and TEM results SEM has been adopted to probe the morphologies of the SnO2 supports, with the images manifested in Fig. 1(a)–(c). Fig. 1(a) displays that the SnO2-Rod support is composed of nano-rods, which were aggregated into microsphere flowers. Fig. 1(b) shows that the SnO2-NP support is assembled by nanoparticles with irregular shapes. In contrast, Fig. 1(c) demonstrates that the SnO2-NP-Cube support with a cubic block shape is successfully prepared. By using different methods, SnO2 supports with varied morphologies have be achieved. TEM images were also collected for 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts to study the morphologies more closely. Fig. 1(d)–(f) indicates that after Pd loading and the second time calcination, the catalysts possess the same morphology to the respective supports, indicating that all the SnO2 supports are physically stable regardless of the morphology. Interestingly, Fig. 1(d) substantiates that the 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod sample consists of structurally uniform SnO2 single crystals. Fig. 1(e) displays that the 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP sample is aggregated by disordered nanoparticles with a mean size of 11.5 nm. Fig. 1(f) shows that the side length of the cubic blocks of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube sample is about 90–150 nm, which is in fact assembled by nanoparticles having porous structures. From the TEM images, it can be identified clearly that both the SnO2-NP-Cube and SnO2-NP supports are intrinsically composed of SnO2 nanoparticles, whose bulk and surface properties could be similar, but very different from that of the SnO2-Rod support. Subsequently, this could influence the Pd distribution and dispersion, [37,50] and the activity of the 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts. 3.2 Activity evaluation Soot oxidation activity/performance of the catalysts was tested with a TPO method. As manifested in Fig. 2(a), without using a catalyst, thermal combustion of the soot particles begins around 500 °C, and reaches the maximum rate around 600 °C (Tp). In contrast, after adding 0.5 % Pd/SnO2, the activity is evidently promoted. Discriminated by the Tp, the activity of the catalysts goes up in the order of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP < 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod < 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube. The soot conversion profiles were depicted in Fig. 2(b), with the T10, T50, T90 and the CO2 selectivity listed in Table 1 for the catalysts. Over 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube, the most active catalyst, the total soot combustion can be realized at 450 °C, which is 30 °C lower than 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod and 80 °C lower than 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP. It is worth noting here that the CO2 selectivity (SCO2) is very low for soot thermal oxidation without a catalyst (68 %). However, with the addition of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts, it is improved to > 96 %, testifying that the deep oxidation addition of soot is promoted significantly. The stability is one of the important criteria to evaluate the application performance of a catalyst. We thus selected the 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube, the best catalyst in this work, to conduct 5 consecutive cycles’ tests. As demonstrated in Fig. S1, the T50 values increased slightly from 405 ℃ to 415 ℃ from the first to the fifth test, testifying that the catalyst is relatively stable during the combustion process. Moreover, we have tested the soot combustion activity of the Pd/SnO2 catalysts under loose contact condition. Fig. S2 displays that under loose contact condition, the T90 of all the catalysts is more or less higher than under tight contact condition. The soot combustion activity of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube and 0.5 % Pd/Al2O3 were compared under the same condition. As shown in Fig. S3, 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube exhibits obviously higher activity than 0.5 % Pd/Al2O3. 3.3 XRD and N2 sorption The crystalline structures of the supports and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts have been analyzed by XRD. Compared with the standard JCPDS card of tetragonal rutile SnO2 in Fig. 3(a), it is obvious that all the SnO2 supports have the same diffraction feature despite the morphology difference. After 0.5 % Pd loading, Fig. 3(b) proves that the pure the rutile SnO2 phase is intact. No any feature of Pd species can be detected, proving that it is dispersed highly on the supports. Whereas, the three supports and the corresponding 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts have apparently different diffraction intensity, indicating that they possess varied crystallinity. Hence, the average crystallite sizes were achieved in Table 2 based on the SnO2 (1 1 0) diffraction peaks of the catalysts. While 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube has the smallest crystallite size of 6.6 nm, 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod has the largest one of 39.4 nm, which is in line with their morphology structures. The crystallinity of the three samples is in the rank of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod > 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP > 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube. In comparison with the pure SnO2 supports, the peak intensity of the Pd/SnO2 catalysts is evidently increased, as indicated by the improved the crystallite sizes, which is believed to be caused by the second time calcination after Pd loading. N2 sorption was employed to discern the textural features of the supports and the corresponding catalysts. As exhibited in Fig. 3(c), 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod is almost non-porous because of its single-crystal structure. However, 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP has a type IV isotherm with a H3 hysteresis loop, and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube has a type IV isotherm with a H2 hysteresis loop, which indicates that they have a porous structure. Compared with 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP, 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube has obviously much larger N2 adsorption-desorption amount, well consistent with the pore volume values in Table 2. As a consequence, 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube has the highest surface area in all the catalysts, while 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod has the smallest one, which matches well the crystallite sizes obtained by XRD. As evidenced in Fig. 3(d), except that 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP might possess some intra-particle pores with an average sized of 4.0 nm, the other two samples could possess inter-particle pores by the assembling of the grains, whose average pore size is larger than 10.0 nm. Compared with the N2 sorption profiles of the supports with different morphologies in Fig. S4, it is apparent that the texture structures of the 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts are mainly decided by that of the respective supports. The loading of a small amount of Pd has nearly no influence on the texture structures of the final catalysts. However, due to the second time calcination, all the Pd/SnO2 catalysts have smaller surface areas, pore volumes and pore sizes than the corresponding supports (Table S1), being consistent to the XRD results. Through analysing the relationship between the specific surface areas and the soot oxidation activity, it was found that 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube sample possessing the largest surface area displays the highest activity. Nevertheless, though 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod has a smaller surface area than 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP, it exhibits still higher activity than the latter. This indicates that a larger specific surface area could be important for soot oxidation, but is not a deciding factor. Some other reasons may be more crucial to influence the catalytic activity. 3.4 H2-TPR, O2-TPD, and soot-TPR studies H2-TPR was employed to probe the redox properties of the catalysts and the respective SnO2 supports. Fig. 4(a) manifests that all the pure supports have one or two major reduction peaks above 500 °C, which is assignable to the SnO2 reducing to metallic Sn. [53] It is mentioned here that SnO2-NP support shows two peaks at 550 and 660 °C, proving that lattice O2− with different chemical environments is present. [54] Judged by the peak temperature, SnO2-Rod support is the most difficult to be reduced because of its single crystal structure with high crystallinity and limited quantity of defects. [28,29] In contrast, SnO2-NP-Cube support is the easiest to be reduced due to its high surface area, low crystallinity with abundant porous structure and defects. With the addition of Pd, the major reduction peaks shift to lower temperatures compared to the respective SnO2 supports, which can be interpreted by the hydrogen spillover effect on formed metallic Pd. [55] After all, this phenomenon demonstrates the presence of interaction between Pd and SnO2 supports, but which is varied due to the differed morphologies, crystallinity and texture properties of the supports. It is noted that the O/Sn molar ratios according to the consumed H2 of the main peak are around 2.0/1.0 ( Table 3), proving that Sn is completely oxidized as Sn4+ in all the samples. More interestingly, the enlarged profiles in Fig. 4(b) display that a minor peak below 400 °C can be seen for all the samples. The reduction of PdOx species usually occurs below 100 °C [32,56]. As reported, the surface of SnO2 owns rich oxygen vacancies/defects, which can adsorb gaseous O2 to generate facile surface electrophilic anions such as O2– and O2 2–. [57,58] Therefore, these minor peaks below 400 °C are attributed to the reducing of surface deficient oxygen anions. [31,53]. As quantified in Table 3, the H2 uptake amount of the supports below 400 °C is ranked as SnO2-Rod < SnO2-NP < SnO2-NP-Cube, implying that the amount of the facile surface oxygen increases in the same sequence. After loading Pd, the amount of these facile surface oxygen drops more or less due to the second time calcination. However, its amount follows still the same sequence. 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube, the most active sample, possesses the largest amount of active surface oxygen. Interestingly, it is worth noting here that though 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod possess a much smaller amount of active surface oxygen than the other two catalysts, it displays still higher performance than 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP. This strongly implies that over the nano-rod shaped sample, some more vital reasons are controlling the activity. O2-TPD was thus conducted to analyze the oxygen characteristics of the catalysts as well as the respective SnO2 supports (Fig. S5(a)). Since all the samples were calcined at 500 °C, and the soot oxidation majorly happened around the same temperature, it is believed that the oxygen species desorbed below 450 °C could contribute crucially to the reaction. Therefore, this part of oxygen sites, which are assignable to the loosely bonded surface oxygen [29,53], are calculated in Table 3. Like the H2-TPR results, the amount of facile surface oxygen on the samples goes up in the order of SnO2-Rod < SnO2-NP < SnO2-NP-Cube. After loading Pd and calcined the second time at 500 °C, the active oxygen amount decreases for all the samples, but following still the same order. While SnO2-NP-Cube possess the largest amount of oxygen species, the SnO2-Rod samples possess the smallest, in good accordance to the H2-TPR results. Soot-TPR results, which are conducted without gaseous O2, can generally provide the information of the interaction between soot particles and the surface oxygen sites. Therefore, the experiments were carried out for the samples and shown in Fig. S5(b). All the samples have some reduction by soot below 600 °C. According to the quantified results in Table 3, the soot reactive oxygen amount basically follows the same sequence to what was detected by O2-TPD. As discussed above, both the SnO2-NP and SnO2-NP-Cube supports are intrinsically composed of SnO2 nano-particles. If prepared into cubic shape with abundant meso-pores, a larger amount of active oxygen can be generated than the regular nano-particles. For 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube, these active oxygen species could contribute significantly to the activity. However, the SnO2-Rod support possesses much smaller amount of active oxygen species than SnO2-NP and SnO2-NP-Cube, the two nano-particle supports. Therefore, the higher activity on 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod than on 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP could mainly originate from some factors other than the active surface oxygen sites. It is postulated that the distribution of the Pd valence states might be an important reason accounting for the activity. 3.5 In-situ DRIFTS, Raman, and EPR studies To elucidate the active oxygen species over the catalysts, in-situ DRIFTS experiments were carried out on both SnO2-NP-Cube support and the corresponding 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube catalyst. As demonstrated above, they contain the largest amount of facile oxygen sites in all the supports and catalysts. First, the catalyst was cleaned in an Ar stream (30 mL min−1) at 400 °C for 60 min, and then cooled to 280 °C. Thereafter, a 10 % O2/Ar stream (30 mL min−1) was directed into the in-situ cell. As displayed in Fig. 5(a) and (b), two typical bands at 775 and 950 cm−1 are observed, which correspond to Sn–O vibration and superoxide O2 −, respectively [57]. The intensity of the O2 − band increases with the extension of the exposing time in the 10 % O2/Ar flow from 1 to 20 min. After this, a 10 % H2/Ar feed (30 mL min−1) was switched into the in-situ cell at the same temperature, and the O2 − peak at 950 cm−1 disappears quickly, while the surface Sn−O remains intact. This indicates that the O2 − species on the catalyst surface can be reduced, but the Sn–O bond is non-reducible at this temperature. Afterwards, the catalyst was re-exposed to the 10 % O2/Ar stream at 280 °C, and the superoxide O2 − species can be fully recovered. In short, the in-situ DRIFTS results have strongly testified that O2 − anions are present on the catalyst surface, which is believed to be the major active oxygen sites devoting to soot oxidation. EPR technique is very keen to detect O2 −, which was thus employed to confirm its formation on all the 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts. Fig. 6(a) shows that two peaks at g = 2.000 and 2.004, which are attributable to the surface O2 − anions, can be evidently observed. [59,60] More interestingly, the intensity/integrated areas of the peaks, which could reflect the relative amount of O2 − anions, increases in the sequence of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod < 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP < 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube, which is well consistent with the H2-TPR, O2-TPD and soot-TPR results. Raman technique was employed to probe the surface feature of the samples. As shown in Fig. 6(b), all the catalysts exhibit the characteristic peaks of rutile SnO2 at 774 and 629 cm−1, which can be assigned to the active Raman modes of B2 g and A1 g. [61] Due to the much lower surface area and higher crystallinity of SnO2-Rod catalyst, its A1 g peak is far more intensive than other two catalysts. Moreover, a band around 645 cm−1 attributable to the vibration mode of Pd−O bond appears on all the Pd/SnO2 catalysts. For Pd/SnO2-Rod sample, the band of Pd−O vibration is much more intensive, which could be due to the better crystallinity of PdOx species on the very low surface area of SnO2-Rod support. [62]. More interestingly, a Raman peak located at 570 cm−1 belonging to the surface oxygen defects/vacancies of SnO2 is detected for all the samples, whose intensity/amount increases in the order of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod < 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP < 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube. It is commonly agreed that the surface defects on a metal oxide can boost the adsorption of gas phase O2 to create facile surface oxygen sites, thus improving its oxidation activity. [24,63,64] Therefore, based on the Raman results, it is not difficult to understand that 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube owns the largest amount of surface active oxygen sites and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod owns the smallest, as also evidenced by the findings with O2-TPD, H2-TPR, and soot-TPR. 3.6 HRTEM and HADDF-mapping analysis Fig. 7 shows the HRTEM images of the Pd/SnO2 catalysts. It can be seen clearly that both 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube are composed of nanoparticle stacking, which is not detected for 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod due to the single crystal structure of the support. Notably, on 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod, distinct Pd/PdO clusters are identified in Fig. 7(b), as proved by the clear diffraction facets of Pd sepcies. However, the facets of Pd/PdO cannot be detected on the 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP. Since the ICP results in Table 1 have testified that the three catalysts contain almost the same amount of Pd species, this strongly indicates that the Pd/PdO species disperses highly on the two nanoparticle SnO2 supports. In contrast, because of the extremely low surface area of SnO2-Rod support and the lack of oxygen vacancies as anchoring sites, [65] severe aggregations of Pd/PdO species has occurred, thus being detectable on the HRTEM images of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod. Indeed, this explains the observation of its strong Pd−O bond vibration signal in the Raman spectroscopy in Fig. 6(b). Fig. 8 shows the elemental distribution of the three catalysts identified by HADDF-mapping. In all the samples, while Sn and O elements distributes very uniformly, the distribution of Pd species is different, in agreement with the fact that Pd/PdO species is impregnated on the catalyst surfaces. As exhibited in Fig. 8(b) and (c), on 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube, it is obvious that the Pd/PdO species spread sparsely over the nanoparticles SnO2 supports with higher surface areas (> 30 m2 g−1). In contrast, on 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod, aggregated Pd/PdO species is evidently detected on the interfaces in Fig. 8(a), due to the very small surface area of SnO2-Rod support, thereby confirming the results of HRTEM and Raman. 3.7 XPS studies To explore the effects of the supports on the state distributions of the supported Pd, all the 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts were analysed by XPS, with the binding energies calibrated by a C 1 s (284.8 eV) internal standard. The C 1 s spectra of the catalysts are shown in Fig. S6, which indicates that carbonate species (288.5 eV) is present on the surfaces of all the Pd/SnO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. S7, all the catalysts display doublet Sn 3d peaks around 486.6 and 495.0 eV, which are assignable to Sn 3d 5/2 and 3d 3/2 of Sn4+ accordingly [30]. In particular, the O 1 s and Pd 3d spectra are analysed in detail for all the catalysts. As exhibited in Fig. 9(a), all the three catalysts display un-symmetric O 1 s peaks, implying the existence of oxygen species in different states. Based on the EPR and in-situ DRIFTS results, the O 1 s spectra are deconvoluted, which can be fitted into four types of oxygen anions, that is, O2 − (532.6 −532.9 eV), CO3 2− (531.4 −532.2 eV), O2 2− (531.4 −531.6 eV) and O2− (529.7 −529.9 eV) [57]. For clear information, the surface (O2 − + O2 2−)/O2− ratios reflecting the active surface oxygen contents are quantified in Table 4 for the catalysts, which increase in the rank of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod < 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP < 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube, matching well the H2-TPR, O2-TPD, soot-TPR,EPR and Raman measurements. Previous literatures reported that the number of active surface oxygen sites is a crucial factor impacting the soot combustion activity [66,67]. But for 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod, some other factors could be more critical to decide its soot oxidation activity, since it displays higher activity than 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP, but contains the smallest amount of facile active surface oxygen sites among all the three catalysts. As manifested in Fig. 9(b), the Pd 3d spectra of the three catalysts are very different from each other, testifying that the Pd state distributions are significantly influenced by the SnO2 supports with different morphologies, texture structures and active oxygen concentrations. Therefore, the Pd 3d spectra of the three catalysts are more closely analysed and quantified in Table 4. The spectrum of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP is fitted with a set of doublet peaks of 3d 5/2 at 337.6 eV and 3d 3/2 at 342.8 eV, indicating that Pd is present solely in a Pd2+ state. [35,68] Nevertheless, besides the Pd2+ species, the close analysis of the Pd 3d spectrum of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube finds the existence of two additional peaks at higher binding energies at 339.4 and 344.3 eV, which can be ascribed to the highly oxidized Pd4+ species such as PdO2. [35,69,70] Former studies have demonstrated that the metastable Pd4+ species have a relatively high catalytic activity. [70] In contrast, the Pd 3d spectrum of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod show that metallic Pd0 species corresponding to binding energies at 335.4 and 341.0 eV are predominantly present, [71] and only a small fraction of Pd2+ species are detected. These findings have strongly substantiated that the abundance of the active oxygen on the SnO2 supports can significantly impact the valence states of the supported Pd. For more distinct information, the average valence states of Pd on the catalysts are calculated in Table 4, which are 0.53, 2.00 and 2.61 for 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod, 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube, respectively. Apparently, on the regular SnO2-NP support, Pd is formed almost 100 % in Pd2+ state over the 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP catalyst. Over SnO2-NP-Cube support with the most abundant active surface oxygen sites, Pd is maintained in highly oxidized states, with the formation of 30.3 % Pd4+ besides 69.7 % Pd2+. However, on the SnO2-Rod support with lean active oxygen, Pd species is in a more reduced state, with the formation of 73.4 % Pd0 and 26.6 % Pd2+ over the 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod catalyst. Based on these experimental facts, it is reasonable to postulate that the Pd valence state distribution should be another critical reason besides surface facile oxygen amount to account for the soot oxidation activity, but it is intimately related to the surface active oxygen contents. 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod catalysts possess dual Pd valence states on the surfaces, hence showing obviously higher soot oxidation activity than 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP. 4 A short discussion With the purpose to achieve active and cost-effective catalysts having the potentials in real soot oxidation, three SnO2 supports possessing varied morphologies have been intentionally designed, and fabricated successfully as supports for Pd to prepare 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts in soot oxidation. As discussed above, XRD, SEM, TEM and HRTEM results have demonstrated that both the SnO2-NP and SnO2-NP-Cube supports are intrinsically composed of SnO2 nano-particles. If assembled into cubic shape, abundant meso-pores are formed, and a larger quantity of active oxygen species can be generated than the regular nano-particles. Since soot combustion generally obeys a Mars-van-Krevelen mechanism on a metal oxide surface, [58] the amount of the active oxygen species ccould contribute importantly to the activity. As compared in Fig. 10(a), 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube possesses a larger quantity of active surface oxygen sites than 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP, hence displaying better activity. Interestingly, though 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod possesses a smaller quantity of active surface oxygen sites than 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP, its displays still higher activity. Therefore, it is trusted that the presence of dual Pd valence states over 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod could be another crucial reason to decide the activity. According to the XPS results, the valence state distributions of Pd on the three SnO2 supports are very different from each other. On the surface of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube, Pd is highly oxidized with 30.3 % Pd4+ and 69.7 % Pd2+ due to the abundance of active surface oxygen species. On the surface of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP, Pd is nearly present as 100 % Pd2+. In contrast, on the surface of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod, Pd is distributed in more reduced states, with 73.4 % Pd0 and 26.6 % Pd2+. Fig. 10(b) exhibits that both 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod possessing dual Pd valence states have obviously higher activity than 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP with only Pd2+, as evidenced by the lower T90. Similar studies have proven that the valence state of noble metal species on the surface is a key factor aﬀecting the activity of the catalysts. [72–74]. Therefore, it is rational to propose that with the co-existence of dual Pd valence states on the catalyst surface, the redox cycles in the Mars-van-Krevelen mechanism can be facilitated remarkably. [58] For instance, on 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube catalyst, the redox cycles can occur easily through Pd4+ ↔ Pd2+; and on 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod catalyst, the redox cycles can occur easily through Pd2+ ↔ Pd0. However, on 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP catalyst, this acceleration effect is not functional since Pd is present as nearly 100 % Pd2+. This expounds that though 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod owns very limited amount of surface active oxygen sites, it shows still considerable soot combustion activity. For 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube, with the combination of the easy redox cycle of Pd and its most abundant active surface oxygen sites, it thus shows the highest activity in all the three catalysts. In conclusion, the abundance of active surface oxygen sites and the existence of Pd with dual valence states are the two predominant reasons deciding the soot combustion activity on 0.5 % Pd/SnO2 catalysts. Inherently, these two factors are closely related to each other. 5 Conclusion To obtain efficient and cost-effective catalysts with the potential for real soot combustion, SnO2 nano-rod (SnO2-Rod), nano-cube (SnO2-NP-Cube) and regular nanoparticles (SnO2-NP) have been intentionally designed and synthesized as supports for Pd. The soot oxidation activity of the catalysts follows the order of 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube > 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod > 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP. The interfacical interactions between Pd and the SnO2 supports with different morphologies have been investigated in detail with multiple techniques. (1) Both SnO2-NP and SnO2-NP-Cube supports are intrinsically composed of SnO2 nanoparticles with mesoporous structure, but SnO2-Rod is composed of rod-shape SnO2 single crystals, which is non-porous. While SnO2-NP-Cube has the highest surface area, SnO2-Rod has the lowest one. As a result, the active oxygen amount of the supports and the Pd/SnO2 catalysts increases in the order SnO2-Rod < SnO2-NP < SnO2-NP-Cube. (2) The active oxygen amount of the SnO2 supports influences remarkably the valence state distributions of the supported Pd. On SnO2-NP support, Pd is nearly present as 100 % Pd2+. On SnO2-NP-Cube support, Pd is in highly oxidized states with 30.3 % Pd4+ and 69.7 %Pd2+. On SnO2-Rod, Pd is in more reduced states with 73.4 % Pd0 and 26.6 % Pd2+. (3) The concerted action of surface active oxygen amount and Pd valence state distribution controls the soot oxidation activity of the catalysts. In detail, the active oxygen sites devote directly to soot oxidation following a Mars-van-Krevelen mechanism. The presence of dual Pd valence states can promote this redox-cycle process. (4) Therefore, although 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod posseses much less surface active oxygen sites than 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP, its shows still better activity due to this promoted redox-cycle. In contrast, with the combination of this promoted redox-cycle and its richest active surface oxygen sites, 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube displays the best activity in all the three catalysts. The results can give people some novel insights on how to develop competitive soot oxidation catalysts by using less amount of noble metal. coredata.dc:description: To manufacture efficient and cost-effective catalysts for soot combustion, SnO2 nano-rod (SnO2-Rod), nano-cube (SnO2-NP-Cube) and regular nanoparticles (SnO2-NP) have been designed as supports for Pd. The soot combustion activity ranks as 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP-Cube > 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod > 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-NP. The active oxygen amount of the supports increases as SnO2-Rod < SnO2-NP < SnO2-NP-Cube, which affects significantly Pd valence state distributions. On SnO2-NP-Cube, Pd is highly oxidized with 30.3 % Pd4+ and 69.7 % Pd2+. On SnO2-NP, nearly 100 % Pd2+ is present. On SnO2-Rod, Pd is more reduced with 73.4 % Pd0 and 26.6 % Pd2+. The concerted action of surface active oxygen and dual Pd valence states determines the activity. In detail, the active oxygen sites devote directly to soot oxidation via a Mars-van-Krevelen mechanism with a redox-cycle. The presence of dual Pd valence states on 0.5 % SnO2-NP-Cube and 0.5 % Pd/SnO2-Rod can promote this redox-cycle, thereby improving the soot combustion activity evidently.
coredata.dc:title: Engineering low Pd content catalysts for soot combustion through tuning the Pd-SnO2 interface interaction: Disclosing the critical role of dual Pd valence states for the activity
